Think of the future, and events that will have already happened.
"By tomorrow, we will have flown to France."

That's it! I am good to go!
Like Christmas when I was a kid.
I mean, how long have I been talking about this?

And it's great. This is great.

Now, I was hoping you could tell me which route the bus will be taking--
Try to remember that! We'll double back for the Chagalls!
What? No. I'm--. I'm just a little tired.
Emma, what have you got in here?
It's from right here that all the highway miles in all of France are measured. They also say that if you stand on this exact spot, you are be destined to return to France in the future.
We were just on our way inside--
But, this is Notre Dame! They need to see this--
Well, what's the point if it's all a big fat blur? When nobody can see anything properly? Let alone experience it, or appreciate--
I've waited my whole life for this trip.
You keep rushing us through, like this is some kind of race--
And you won't even speak French with me.
Now, I think I've been very nice.
Now, the real tour can begin!
Who cares? We're in Paris! What's a little rain?

No. It's okay. You were right--
Oh, Meg! I made a huge mistake!
Richard asked me to marry him--
I told him we should wait a week!
I'd imagined him asking me a million times, but then when he did, I just panicked. suddenly all I could think about was the trip.

That I hadn't already been to France. It was like this wave, all the years, and chances I'd had but didn't take, they just crashed down on me: And I hadn't seen anything but the end of Lake Avenue. The only clear thought in my head was, "this guy is so wonderful, how can he marry half a person?"
I thought he was asking me to make a choice. But, he wasn't. He wasn't doing that at all. It was me. Because I couldn't believe he loved me just for who I was.
